title: 106_hr1822
content: The Act is titled the "Emergency Steel Loan Guarantee Program" and includes findings related to the program. Congress finds that the U.S. steel industry suffered severely in 1998 due to a surge of steel imports caused by the world financial crisis. This led to job losses, bankruptcies of medium-sized steel companies, reduced volume, lower prices, financial losses, and difficulty in obtaining credit for operations and reinvestment. Private banks and investment institutions were also reluctant to provide loans to the U.S. steel industry. The U.S. steel industry faced challenges in 1998 due to a surge in steel imports, leading to job losses, bankruptcies, and financial difficulties. Banks were hesitant to provide loans for operations and reinvestment. The industry's struggles have negative effects on tax bases and essential services, while a strong steel industry is crucial for national defense preparedness. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms such as "Board" as the Loan Guarantee Board, "Program" as the Emergency Steel Guaranteed Loan Program, and "qualified steel company" as a company engaged in steel production that has experienced layoffs or financial losses. Since January 1, 1998, steel companies have faced financial losses due to the import crisis. Establishment of Emergency Steel Guaranteed Loan Program by the Loan Guarantee Board, consisting of the Secretary of Commerce, Secretary of Labor, and Secretary of the Treasury, to provide loan guarantees to qualified steel companies. The Emergency Steel Guaranteed Loan Program allows the Program to guarantee loans for qualified steel companies up to $1,000,000,000 in total and $250,000,000 per company. Loans must be at least $25,000,000, and the Board must approve or deny applications promptly. The Emergency Steel Guaranteed Loan Program authorizes $140,000,000 for additional loan costs. Loan guarantees can be issued to qualified steel companies if credit is not available under reasonable terms and the company's earning power is sufficient. The Emergency Steel Guaranteed Loan Program authorizes $140,000,000 for additional loan costs. Loan guarantees can be issued to qualified steel companies if credit is not available under reasonable terms and the company's earning power is sufficient. The company must meet certain criteria for the loan guarantee, including the prospective earning power, security value, reasonable interest rate, and agreement to audits by the General Accounting Office. All guaranteed loans must be fully repaid by December 31, 2005. The loan terms must be repaid by December 31, 2005, without amendments or waivers. Loan guarantees require appropriate covenants and security. A fee of 0.5% of the outstanding balance is payable to the Treasury. The Secretary of Commerce must report annually to Congress on the activities of the Board under this Act for fiscal years 1999 and 2000, and thereafter as long as any guaranteed loan is outstanding. SEC. 7 authorizes $5,000,000 for administrative expenses. SEC. 8 ends loan guarantee commitments by December 31, 2001. SEC. 9 mandates final rules within 60 days of enactment. SEC. 10 pertains to iron ore companies. SEC. 10 allows iron ore companies to be treated as qualified steel companies under the Program, with a total guarantee limit of $30,000,000 for loans outstanding. A single loan to an iron ore company of at least $6,000,000 may be guaranteed. SEC. 11. EMERGENCY DESIGNATION. The entire amount made available to carry out this Act is designated by Congress as an emergency requirement and shall be available only if an official budget request is transmitted by the President.
